title: Analyzing Primary Sources: Civil War Era
objective: Students will analyze a primary source document and evaluate the historical claims it makes.

activities.name: Prior Knowledge Activation
instructions: Think of a historical event you know well
Consider: What sources tell us about that event?
Share one example with a partner

support: Provide example events for students to choose from
Pair struggling students with supportive partners
extension: Ask students to categorize their sources (primary vs secondary)

activities.name: Introduction to Primary Sources
instructions: Define 'primary source' as a firsthand account from the time of an event
Identify types of primary sources: letters, diaries, photographs, official documents
Contrast with secondary sources: textbooks, encyclopedias, documentaries
Take notes on the key characteristics
activities.assessment_method: Check for understanding questions during instruction
key_points: Secondary = created later, about the event

extension: Have students find additional examples online

activities.name: Document Analysis Practice
instructions: Read the provided Civil War letter carefully
Identify who wrote it, when, and to whom
Note the author's perspective and potential biases
Complete the SOAP analysis worksheet (Speaker, Occasion, Audience, Purpose)
activities.assessment_method: Worksheet review for accuracy and depth
reflection_questions: What surprised you about this source?
What questions does this source raise?

support: Allow partner work for struggling students
extension: Compare with a second primary source from different perspective

activities.name: Evaluating Historical Claims
instructions: Identify 2-3 historical claims made in the primary source
Evaluate the evidence supporting each claim
Rate the reliability of each claim (strong/moderate/weak)
Justify your ratings with specific evidence from the source
activities.student_output: Completed claim evaluation chart with justifications
activities.assessment_method: Partner review followed by class discussion
key_points: What claims does the author make?

support: Pre-identify one claim for students to evaluate
Provide examples of strong vs weak evidence
extension: Research additional sources to corroborate or challenge claims

activities.name: Exit Ticket
instructions: Answer the exit ticket questions independently

hidden_slide_content.objective: Students will analyze a primary source document and evaluate the historical claims it makes.
misconceptions: Students may think all old documents are primary sources (age does not determine primary vs secondary)
Students may confuse objectivity with reliability (biased sources can still be reliable for certain purposes)
Students may think primary sources are always more accurate than secondary sources
delivery_tips: Use a document relevant to your current unit - Civil War letters work well for this topic
Model the SOAP analysis process with a practice document before independent work
Circulate during analysis activity to provide targeted feedback
Leave time for class discussion of claim evaluations - differences in interpretation are valuable

vocabulary.definition: A firsthand account or direct evidence from the time of an event, created by someone who experienced or witnessed it
An account or analysis created after an event by someone who did not directly experience it
A tendency to favor one perspective, viewpoint, or outcome over others
The trustworthiness and accuracy of a source's information
Confirming information by comparing it with other sources

assessment.description: Quick check of primary source analysis skills learned in today's lesson
questions: What makes a source 'primary' rather than 'secondary'? Give one example of each.
What is one way to identify potential bias in a primary source?
Why is it important to evaluate the reliability of historical claims?

metadata.notes: This sample lesson exceeds the 40% higher-order thinking minimum with 70% (analysis + knowledge_utilization)
